En el futuro ella planea comprar ropa para venderla, y as tener un ingreso mas D. dinero en casa, por lo que tambien tiene miras D. alquilar o comprar un stand o puesto donD. ella pueda vender aquellas prendas D. vestir. Suea con terminar D. construir su casa, y comprar un auto el cual lo alquilara. Celinda usar el prtamos para comprar productos D. belleza y ofrecerlos a su clientela mas selecta.
texts.en:
"SANTISIMA TRINIDAD" (HOLY TRINITY) Communal Bank. The "SANTISIMA TRINIDAD" (HOLY TRINITY) Communal Bank has been working with EDAPROSPO-PROSPERIDAD for over two years. It has 8 members who live in the same neighborhood and who have formed a strong friendship bond over the years. Among them is Celinda who is the mother of a son who is now independent. She is a factory employee and also sells beauty products to her acquaintances, friends and coworkers. In the future shed like to buy clothing to sell so that her income will be higher. She also is looking to buy or rent a stand where she can sell those clothing items. She dreams with finishing her house and buy a car to lease out. Celinda will use the loan to buy beauty products to offer to her best customers.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: To buy assorted beauty products.

loan.name: Martha

texts.es:
Martha naci en la ciudad de Sicuani de la provincia de Canchis del departamento del Cusco. Antiguamente la ciudad del Cusco fue la capital del Imperio inca y una de las ciudades ms importantes del Virreinato del Per.
Al cumplir mayora de edad, Martha decidi estudiar para ser profesora y estudio en el prestigioso instituto superior pedaggico Santa Rosa del Cusco. Actualmente, Martha trabaja como profesora del nivel inicial en el colegio "283 de Ccatcapampa" en la comunidad de Ccatca, donde ella tambin vive.
Con su prximo prstamo, Martha espera recibir $500 USD. Utilizar el dinero del prstamo para hacer sus trmites de su diploma de bachillerato y tambin para apoyar a su ta que vende tamales de forma ambulatoria.
Sus anhelos de Martha es terminar la maestra que est estudiando y abrir un jardn en la ciudad del Cusco y tambin abrir una tienda de venta de juguetes para bebes.
texts.en:
Martha was born in the city of Sicuani, Canchis province, Cusco department. In the past, Cusco was the capital of the Inca Empire and one of the most important cities of the Per Viceregency. When Martha became of age, she decided she wanted to be a teacher. She studied at Cuscos prestigious Santa Rosa superior pedagogical institute. She is currently teaching elementary school at 283 de Ccatcapampa school in Ccata, which is where she also lives. Martha expects to receive $500 USD in her next loan. She will use the funds to pay expenses related to her getting her diploma and also to help her aunt who is an itinerant tamale vendor. Marthas dream is to finish the Masters degree shes currently working on and open a kindergarten in Cusco. She also wants to open a toy store for babies.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: For diploma expenses.

loan.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace M. is from the village of D'ban, Calamba. She is 38 years old, married, and has three school-aged children. To make a living, she owns a coco logging business. She's able to earn a monthly net income of $183 from selling coco lumber in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for more than five years.
In 2000, Grace joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used as additional capital for her business. Grace is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP which will be used to invest in rice retailing. This will be her 5th loan from PMPC.
About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.
*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loan.use: To invest in rice retailing

loan.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn D. is from the village of Tumpagon, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 43 years old. Evelyn is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Evelyn owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food & daily use products and also baking and selling a variety of breads in the local community. Evelyn has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month for these activities.
In 2008, Evelyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Evelyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Evelyn is requesting a new loan of 17000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This loan will be the 5th loan taken out by Evelyn from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the business.
About HSPFI:
HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.
*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loan.use: to purchase additional inventory & working capital

loan.name: Nguyn

texts.en:
N. Nguyn Th T. (20201020020), a 33 year old woman living in the town of huyn Yn Phong - tnh Bc Ninh, is married and has two school-aged children. To making a living, N. owns and operates a business venture providing general services to community members. Engaged in this business for over 11 years, she earns approximately 4.200.000 VND a month.
In 2007, N. joined SEDA to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having repaid her previous loan of 6.048.000 VND from SEDA that was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital, she is now requesting a new loan of 8.288.000 VND to purchase materials needed to expand services provided. This will be N.'s fourth loan from SEDA, and she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her enterprise.
About SEDA:
The mission of SEDA (Center of Small Enterprise Development Assistance) is to provide microfinance services to the low income and disadvantaged people in rural areas of Hanoi and the Northern provinces of VietN..
*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loan.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita Q. is from the village of Balzain west, Tuguegarao City. She is 49 years old. Teresita is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Teresita owns & operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap & toothpaste in the local community. Teresita has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month for these activities.
In 2010, Teresita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Teresita is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the first loan taken out by Teresita from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.
About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

loan.name: Yun

texts.en:
Mrs. Yun T. is a middle-aged woman whose husband appears in the photo here. Yun T. owns a small store along the road located near the garment factory where she sells food to sewing laborers to earn a living. She is married with two school-aged kids, while her husband is a construction foreman who has a few employees help him to provide his service.
Yun T.s husband is running his service well because he is widely known in construction and has skills in public relations which he uses with his customers. However, his income is not very big as his service has recently come to a low capacity due to insufficient financial capital. So, Yun T. requests a loan for her husband to increase his capital which will allow him to improve his profits. Mrs. Yun T. was not available on that day so her husband is pictured instead.

loan.use: To increase the business capital

loan.name: Nghim's Group

texts.en:
H. Nghim Th is a 29-year-old woman living in the town of huyn Yn Phong - tnh Bc Ninh. H. is the group leader of a 3-member group loan offered by SEDA. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Nghim X nhm 09 (Nhm 09).
H. is married and has 1 school-aged child. To making a living, H. works in the services sector operating a tailoring business. The main source of income for the business comes from providing specialty tailoring services to local community members. H. has been engaged in this business for over 1 year and earns approximately 2,800,000 VND a month.
In 2007, H. joined SEDA to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,600,000 VND from SEDA, which was used to purchase additional inventory & as working capital. She is now requesting a new loan of 7,392,000 VND, which will be used to invest in renovating the business. This will be H.s 4th loan from SEDA. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand it.
About the Other Borrowers in the Group:

2. Nghim Th Lng is a 29 year-old woman who is requesting a 5,152,000 VND loan to support her business in the agriculture sector raising livestock.
About SEDA:
The mission of SEDA (Center of Small Enterprise Development Assistance) is to provide microfinance services to the low income and disadvantaged people in rural areas of Hanoi and the Northern provinces of Vietnam.

Hu has been engaged in this business for over 3 years and earns approximately 3,000,000 VND a month.
In 2009, Hu joined SEDA to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,152,000 VND from SEDA, which was used to purchase additional products to sell. She is now requesting a new loan of 8,288,000 VND, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be Hus 2nd loan from SEDA. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand it.
About SEDA:
The mission of SEDA (Center of Small Enterprise Development Assistance) is to provide microfinance services to the low income and disadvantaged people in rural areas of Hanoi and the Northern provinces of Vietnam.
*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loan.use: to invest in expanding the business

loan.name: Hang's Group

texts.en:
Hang T. P. is the leader of a 5-member loan group from SEDA. She was born in 1987. She lives in Duong Nhan village, where she grows rice and raises pigs. She has two children who are still young. Her husband is a mechanic, and together they have a monthly income of about 4,000,000 VND. Hang T. P. would like to borrow 5,014,000 VND to help her breed her pigs. This is her first loan from SEDA.
About other borrowers in her group:
Hien T. N. was born in 1981. She raises pigs. She has a monthly income of about 4,000,000 VND. She would like to borrow 5,014,000 VND in order to buy food for her pigs.
Huynh D. N. was born in 1960. He breeds pigs. He wants to borrow 5,014,000 VND to invest in livestock.
Son V. D. was born in 1984. He raises chickens, and wants to borrow 5,014,000 VND to buy food for them.
Thien D. N. was born in 1980. He has three children. He breeds poultry, and would like to borrow 5,014,000 VND in order to buy food for his animals.

loan.use: to breed her pigs

loan.name: Dan's Group

texts.en:
Dan T. N. was born in 1974. She lives in Luong Quy village with her husband and two sons. She not only grows rice but also sells clothes in the market. She has a monthly income of about 6,000,000 VND. This is the first time she has participated in SEDA. She would like to borrow 5,014,000 VND in order to invest in her clothing shop. She is the leader of a 6-member loan group from SEDA.
About other borrowers in her group: Nu T. D. was born in 1955. She has a store, and would like to borrow 5,014,000 VND in order to expand it. Huyen T. T. N. was born in 1971. She is a tailor, and would like to borrow 5,014,000 VND in order to buy cloth. Bon T. N. was born in 1951. She is raising 9 pigs, and would like to borrow 5,014,000 VND in order to buy food for them. Giang T. N. was born in 1984. She has a daughter. She would like to borrow 5,014,000 VND in order to repair her house. Tham T. N. was born in 1955. She would like to borrow 5,014,000 VND in order to breed poultry.

loan.use: To invest in her clothing shop.

loan.name: Bekzhan

texts.en:
Bekzhan A. is 35 years old and lives with his family in the neighborhood of Kyz-Molo village. He has two daughters: four and two years old. At his country place, Bekzhan is known as a hard-working and energetic person.
Bekzhan was born in a farmworkers family and, from early childhood helped his parents in farming. Over the years, he inherited the farm and a house near it. Gaining a wide experience in stockmanship, 15 years ago Bekzhan started his business in cattle breeding, which became the main source of income for his family. Due to his strong efforts, Bekzhan has developed his farm and today it amounts to ten milk cows and five bulls. Bekzhan and his wife sell milk to their loyal customers and have earnings of 10,000 Kyrgyz Soms monthly.
Bekzhan plans to use the loan of 90,000 Kyrgyz Soms to broaden his business through buying three milk cows, which will allow for increased milk sales. With the revenues from the loan, he plans to broaden his business by purchasing more cattle.
Bekzhan is doing his best to provide good conditions in which his children can develop.
Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading Microfinance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loan.use: To purchase cattle.

loan.name: Vergie

texts.en:
Vergie M. is from the village of Bantuanon, Lantapan, Bukidnon. She is 42 years old. Vergie is separated from her spouse and has 5 adult children. To make a living, Vergie owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising ducks for sale. Vergie has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.
In 2010, Vergie joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Vergie is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Vergie from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.
About HSPFI:
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.
*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loan.use: To purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future.

loan.name: Angelita

texts.en:
Angelita L. is from the village of Poblacion, Lantapan, Bukidnon. She is 49 years old. Angelita is married and has 4 adult children. To make a living, Angelita owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food & daily use products and also buying and selling bananas and vegetables in the local community. Angelita has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.
In 2010, Angelita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Angelita is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Angelita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.
About HSPFI:
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loan.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loan.name: Evangeline

texts.en:
Evangeline D. is from the village of Bacnor East. She is 45 years old. Evangeline is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Evangeline owns & operates a service-based business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from providing repair services to local community members. Evangeline has been engaged in her business for over 7 years and earns approximately 4,500 PHP a month for these activities.
In 2007, Evangeline joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Evangeline has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase materials needed to provide service. Evangeline is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase equipment to improve the business. This loan will be the eighth loan taken out by Evangeline from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children.
About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.
*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loan.use: To purchase equipment to improve the business.

loan.name: Ngveang

texts.en:
Mrs. Ngveang T. sells fresh fish in the market to earn a living. Every day in the late morning, she goes to a place where fishermen sell fish in bulk. Then she hurries to bring the fish to the market, where she sells them retail. Ngveang T. has another financial earner in her husband who appears in the photograph here. He works in the construction sector. The couple has two teenage children who work as hairdressers.
Ngveang T. runs her business well because she sells at reasonable prices and has skills in public relations which she uses with her customers. Recently, Ngveang T. received orders for lots of fish from her regular customers, but she lacks the capital to better meet her customers' requirements. This is why she has decided to ask for a Kiva loan.

loan.use: To provide more capital to better meet her customers' requirements.

loan.name: Lilibeth

texts.en:
Lilibeth S. is from the village of Poblacion, Lantapan, Bukidnon. She is 34 years old. Lilibeth is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Lilibeth owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Lilibeth has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month for these activities.
In 2010, Lilibeth joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lilibeth is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Lilibeth from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.
About HSPFI:

loan.name: Miriam

texts.en:
Miriam G. is from the village of Villa Concepcion, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 40 years old. Miriam is married and has 2 adult children. To make a living, Miriam owns and operates a restaurant. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from serving lunch to customers in the local community. Miriam has been engaged in her business for over 9 years and earns approximately 5,500 PHP a month for these activities.
In 2009, Miriam joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Miriam is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase food and drinks for the restaurant. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Miriam from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. She hopes that KIVA lenders will continue to share their blessings with small entrepreneurs like her.
About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

To make a living, Jocelyn owns and operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling seafood products, including fish and shrimp, in the local community. loan.name: Marinel

texts.en:
Marinel M. is from the village of Allinguigan 3rd. She is 34 years old. Marinel is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Marinel owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for fattening and sale. Marinel has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP when she sells her raised animals. Marinel said that the business is of big help in supporting their family's needs.
In 2009, Marinel joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marinel has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future. Marinel is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in future. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Marinel from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.
About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loan.use: To purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future.

To make a living, Cecerna owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food and daily use products in the local community. loan.name: Loep

texts.en:
Mrs. S., 36, is married to Res Minh, age 41, and they have two school-aged kids.
S. combines various types of root trees to create natural medicine to examine people who are her nearby neighbors. This skill she learned from her grandparent, who died of senility years ago. As another source of family income, she has a life partner in her husband, who buys and sells vehicle,. He always buys secondhand motorcycles at cheap prices, and then repairs/paints them for a while before selling them to raise revenue. Because the vehicle selling business is an important source of family income and in order to earn additional income, S. has decided to borrow a loan for her husband to buy more vehicles to resell.

loan.use: To buy more vehicles to resell.

loan.name: Maricris

texts.en:
Maricris C. is from the village of Allinguigan 3rd. She is 38 years old. Maricris is married and has 6 infant children. To make a living, Maricris owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector running a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Maricris has been engaged in her business for over 7 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.
In 2009, Maricris joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Maricris has successfully repaid a previous loan of 9,800 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Maricris is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Maricris from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.
About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.
*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loan.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loan.name: Sip

texts.en:
Sip H. is a 59 year old rice and vegetable grower from Battambang Province. She runs her business on her own farmland, where she grows different kinds of crops like cabbage, rice, and morning glories. She will sell the crops to a buyer when they have matured.
Sip H. is a widowed woman and the mother of three kids. She has another financial earner in her daughter, in the photograph above, who sells a few snack foods to earn a living. Sip H. requests a loan of $600 to be used to buy a used motorcycle to make family transportation easier. She proposes to plant crops by using any remaining cash from the loan.

loan.use: To buy a used motorcycle.

loan.name: Sokhorn

texts.en:
Mrs. Sokhorn Y. (pictured here), is 58 years old and her husband, Mr. Kong Phoung, is 59 years old, and they live along National Road Number One about eighteen kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were married in 1970 and have eight children: five sons and three daughters. Four of them are married and live outside the family home, three are construction workers, and other one is a traditional musician.
Sokhorn has been a vegetable farmer for seven years. Her husband has been a traditional musician for thirty years. She is asking for her first loan in the amount of 1,000 USD to buy a motorcycle for her children to drive to work.

loan.use: To purchase a motorbike for her children to drive to work.

loan.name: Sary

texts.en:
Mr. Sary V. is a driver; he drives for a company in Phnom Penh City. His wife is a garment factory worker. They have been married since 2008, and have no children. The family lives in a village along National Road Number one, approximately fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh.
Sary is asking for his first loan of $500 to purchase a motorbike for commuting to work.
In the photo is Sarys mother, because he and his wife were at work when the photo was taken.

loan.use: To buy a motorcycle for commuting to work.

loan.name: Siren

texts.en:
Mrs. Siren K., is 27 years old and her husband, Ms. Sophearak Keo, is 28 years old, and they have been married since 2005. They have two children: one son and one daughter. All of them are still young. They live with their parents about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh City.
Siren and her husband are farmers. They grow cauliflowers and beans on their farmland in the village. The family depends on their farming business, which is the main source of income. They do not have enough capital to purchase seed, fertilizer and pesticide to maintain their farm and pay for plowing fees.
Therefore, Siren is asking for her first loan of $1,000 help her capital.
In the photo Siren is at home, not on the farm.

loan.use: To use for growing cauliflowers.

loan.name: Reun

texts.en:
Mr. Reun K., 57 (pictured with his wife) and his wife, Mrs. Sokha Long, 56, live in a village along National Road Number one, about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh City. They have been married since 1980 and have seven children - four sons and three daughters. Three of them are married and live in separate homes, two are security guards, and the other two are garment factory workers.
Reun has been a motor taxi driver since 1990. His wife sells porridge in the village. He is requesting his first loan of $1,200 to purchase a motorbike for his children to drive to work. He also will use a part of the loan to repair the house where he lives.

loan.use: To purchase a motorcycle for his children to drive to work and repair the house where he lives.

loan.name: Sokhan

texts.en:
Mrs. Sokhan K. (pictured here), and her husband, Mr. Thouk Mao, got married in 1994 and now have two daughters. Both of them are in school. They are living on an island in the MeK. River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

Sokhan is a silk weaver. She sells her finished products to the middleman in the village, who then takes them to sell in Phnom Penh. Her husband has been a vegetables farmer for more than 22 years.

The family has requested a Kiva loan one time already. Sokhan is now asking for another US$100 to help supply her husband with the capital to purchase fertilizer and pesticide to maintain his vegetable farm, so that he can continue to increase the volume of vegetables.

loan.use: To provide capital for her husbands farming business.

loan.name: Thach

texts.en:
Mrs. Thach P. (in the photo), is 50 years old and lives in a suburb of Phnom Penh. She is a widow with two sons and three daughters. One of her sons is married and lives outside the family home and the other one attends school. All of her daughters are garment factory workers.

Thach has been selling boiled eggs and grilled beef at her home for more than a year. She has previously taken out a Kiva loan to purchase a motorbike for her daughters to drive to work. She is now applying for another loan of $900 to buy another motorbike for her son to drive to school.

loan.use: To purchase a motorbike for her son to drive to school.

loan.name: Bunnet

texts.en: Mr. Bunnet M. (not in the photo; his wife is pictured instead) and his wife, Mrs. Sreytoch Thoeun, have been married since 1998 and have four children. The family lives on an island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. Bunnet has full-time employment in Phnom Penh. His wife weaves silk at home and takes care of their children. Bunnet is requesting a loan of $550 to purchase a motorbike for commuting.

loan.use: To purchase a motorbike for commuting.

loan.name: Van

texts.en: Mrs. Van P. currently cultivates various crops to earn a living. She is 52 years old and a resident of Battambang province, located about 280 km from the capital, Phnom Penh. She is a single mother, with seven children who are all single. Van P. also relies on the income from her daughter who mends and sews clothes in the village. Van P. wishes to have more income to ensure that her family can meet their current expenses with more stability. To achieve her goal, Van P. would like to invest in a new business of buying and selling mature rice in bulk, but she is concerned that she doesnt have enough money yet to begin the process. Therefore, Van P. is humbly requesting a loan in order to buy 2000 kg of rice to store for a while before selling it at a profit. Mrs. Van P. was not available when the photograph was taken, so her daughter is pictured instead.

loan.use: To buy 2000 kg of rice for resale.

loan.name: Virginia

texts.en:
Virginia L. is from the village of Poblacion, Lantapan, Bukidnon. She is 47 years old. Virginia is married and has three adult children. To make a living, Virginia owns and operates a business making and selling food. The main source of income for the business comes from selling specialty food products like special macaroni salad in a plastic container in the local community. Virginia has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Virginia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Virginia is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Virginia from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve and expand the business.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loan.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale.

loan.name: Haki Sawa Group

texts.en:
Zuhura Abdallah, age 33, is single and has two children ages 8 and 15 years. She has operated a caf business for 2 years now. She works from 7am to 4 pm daily and she is able to make a monthly profit of about $129.
This will be Zuhura second motisha loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. A Motisha loan is a product offered by Tujijenge Tanzania that allows borrowers with good credit ratings to pay back their original loans faster and receive extra money before their original loan term has ended. She used the previous motisha loan to increase on her business stock and she has paid back the loan successfully. She hopes for a new motisha loan to buy more items for her caf such as utensils, chairs, rice and flour. She hopes that her business continues to improve and grow, so that she can continue to help her family.
Zuhura will share this loan with her loan group, Haki Sawa, which has 15 members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable in paying back the loan. In the picture, Zuhura is the woman wearing the plaid kilemba (hair wrap) with a white t-shirt, sitting in the front row.

loan.use: To buy utensils, chairs, flour and rice for cafe.

loan.name: Mom

texts.en:
Mrs. Mom S. A. is a married mother caring for two kids. Both of them attend the local school and are dependent on her income. Her husband is a professional teacher who teaches the secondary class.
To earn a living, Mom S. A. sells fish paste that she buys in bulk from her supplier. She also buys fresh fish and turns them into fish paste.
Mom S. A. is concerned that her current business has come to a low capacity due to insufficient financial capital. She wishes to have more money to increase her capital which will allow her to improve her profits. This is why she has decided to ask for a Kiva loan. (Mrs. Mom S.'s husband is pictured.)

loan.use: To increase her capital

loan.name: Gombo

texts.en:
Gombo A. is 47 years old and lives with his wife and four children in Uvs province, western Mongolia, in their own ger, a traditional nomadic housing tent. The elder son is a student, while the other children attend a local middle school.
Gombo began his business in 2000 with the help of his wife. They sew a variety of shoes and clothing including deels, traditional Mongolian garments, and other coats that are suitable for the spring and fall weather in Mongolia. Since managing their business successfully, Gombo and his wife have been able to afford their children's tuition fees.
Gombo also makes hay from two hectares (five acres) of land once a year and sells the hay in autumn. He is requesting a 700,000 MNT loan to use for cutting the hay.

loan.use: To cut hay

loan.name: Classic Group

texts.en:
Fedrick Mikael, age 37, is married with four children aged 15, 14, 13 and 9 years. In the picture, Fedrick is sitting in the front row, first on the right wearing a white shirt.
Fedrick has been selling food items at his shop for two years now. He works from 6 a.m. to 9 p.m. and is able to make a monthly profit of about $129.
This will be Fedricks second motisha loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. A motisha loan is a product offered by Tujijenge Tanzania that allows borrowers with good credit ratings to pay back their original loans faster and receive extra money before their original loan term has ended.
Fedrick used his previous motisha loan to improve his shop and he has managed to pay back the loan successfully. He hopes for a new motisha loan to buy more food items such as salt, sugar, flour and rice. His dream is to buy more products to increase the stock in his shop.
Fedrick will share this loan with his loan group, Classic, which totals eight members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable in paying back the loan.

loan.use: To buy more food items such as salt, sugar, flour and rice for his shop

loan.name: Baatarjav

texts.en:
Baatarjav D. is 48 years old and lives with his wife and two children in Uvs province, western Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. His son was demobilized from the army this year and his daughter is a student in a university.
Baatarjav operates a shoemaking business in his town and his wife helps him with sewing the shoes. He sews many types of shoes including the traditional Mongolian shoes which are well known as a pair of white-soled shoes which are popular and warm and valued by his customers for their quality and design.
Baatarjav began this business in 1990 and since then he has gained a lot of experience and knows what his customers want and how much they are willing to pay for his quality shoes. He sells his products to stock keepers through trade fairs or by wholesale. The business has been so successful that he purchased a car which allows him to deliver his products to his customers.
Baatarjav is requesting a 2,000,000 MNT loan in order to purchase more fabrics and finishing materials for his business.

loan.use: To purchase more fabrics and finishing materials for his business

loan.name: Math

texts.en:
Math F. is a young woman whose husband appears in the photograph. Math F. lives with another family member in the capital of Phnom Penh. She has rented a market store, where she sells chickens to earn a living. She and her husband usually go to buy chicken in bulk at the cheapest price possible from rural people whose houses are full of the poultry they raise.
Math F.'s business has recently come to a low capacity due to insufficient financial capital. Math F. would like to seek a loan on Kiva through HKLs project. She will be using her loan to increase her capital, which will allow her to improve her profits.

loan.use: To increase her capital

loan.name: Luvisminda's Group

texts.en:
Luvisminda G. is from the village of San Bernardo. She is 58 years old. Luvisminda is the group leader of a 5-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is 'Luvisminda G.'.
Luvisminda is married and has 3 adult children. To make a living, Luvisminda owns & operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Luvisminda has been engaged in her business for over 14 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.
In 2010, Luvisminda joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Luvisminda is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the first loan taken out by Luvisminda from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.
About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

loan.name: Erdenebileg

texts.en:
Erdenebileg B. is 40 years old and lives with his wife and three children in Uvs province, western Mongolia. He and his family have been living together in a house for 9 years. Erdenebileg began his carpentry business in 2003. He produces 'ger'--a traditional Mongolian housing tent--parts such as wooden walls, doors and poles, which make up a 'ger' roof while his wife sews shoes which are well-known as a pair of white-soled shoes, popular and warm.
Erdenebileg and his wife are working hard to expand their product line to include furniture as well. Erdenebileg would one day like to open a small factory in which he can produce even more products with ease. He is requesting a 500,000 MNT loan in order to purchase more wood, fabrics, finishing materials and supplies in order to expand his business and keep up with customers orders.

loan.use: To purchase materials for his and his wife's businesses

loan.name: Chhun

texts.en:
Mrs. Chhun R. is an older woman and is the mother of three teenage children. She is a good housewife who arranges a daily routine and takes care of the kids. The family's livelihood is contributed to by Chhun R.s husband who works in the MinistR. of the Interior. Another source of family income comes from Chhun R.s daughter who works as a waitress in a restaurant located in the middle of Phnom Penh city.
Chhun R. is taking out her first loan to repair/decorate her old house, where she plans to operate a small business in the future. (Mrs. Chhun R.s daughter is pictured.)

loan.use: To repair/re-decorate her old house, where she plans to operate a small business in the future

loan.use: to invest in renovating the business

loan.name: Bekkul

texts.en:
Bekkul A. was born into a family of farm workers, where cattle-breeding was passed on from one generation to another. From early childhood, he helped his parents in farming and animal breeding. After graduating from secondary school and serving in the army, he returned home and got a job at a local farm.

Later, after marrying and becoming a father of three children, Bekkul decided to start his own business in cattle breeding. Using his starting capital of 3,000 Kyrgyz Soms, he bought one milk cow and, owing to a persistent and hardworking personality, managed to multiply his investments. Presently, his farm has 3 milk cows, 20 sheep and 2 bulls. Last year, Bekkul applied for a loan to buy cattle and repaid it without any delays.

Bekkul plans to use this loan of 65,000 Kyrgyz Soms to increase his number of cattle for fattening and reselling, and in the future he plans to buy a car for his elder son and hold his wedding.

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading Microfinance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loan.use: To purchase cattle

loan.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose P., from the village of Bantuanon, Lantapan, Bukidnon, is 34 years old, married, and has five school-aged children. To make a living, Rose owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Engaged in her business for over a year, she earns approximately 4000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Rose joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Now requesting her first loan for 5000 PHP to purchase additional products to sell, she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her store.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

To help contribute to her family, her husband works as a teacher in the secondary school (he appears in the photo). This couple have been married for years and they have four children, three of whom are now married and the other is single.
In order to reduce her transportation costs, Cheth M. is applying for a loan to buy a used motorbike that she will use to either transport her inventory or to travel anywhere.

loan.name: Kapamba Group

texts.en:
Elizabeth M., age 35, is single with two children who are 13 and 16 years old. She has operated a beauty salon and a cafe for three years now. She works from 7 am to 10 pm daily and she is able to make a monthly profit of about $200.
This will be Elizabeths first motisha loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. A motisha loan is a product offered by Tujijenge Tanzania that allows borrowers with good credit ratings to pay back their original loans faster and receive extra money before their original loan term has end. She hopes for a new motisha loan to buy supplies for her salon and her caf. Her dream is to buy a more hair dryers and steamers and continue widening her caf to become international.
Elizabeth will share this loan with her loan group, Kapampa, which has seven members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable in paying back the loan.
In the picture, Elizabeth is in the center wearing a colored blouse.

loan.use: To buy supplies for her salon and cafe.

To make a living, Jessa runs a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling both food and daily use products in her local community. Jessa has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month for these activities.
In 2010, Jessa joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jessa is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Jessa from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.
About HSPFI:
HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.
*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loan.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loan.name: Mryna

texts.en:
Mryna R. is from the village of San Roque. She is 56 years old. Mryna is married and has five grown-up children. To make a living, Mryna raises pigs for sale. Mryna has been engaged in her business for more than four years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities.
In 2000, Mryna joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Mryna has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC. Mryna is requesting a new loan of 20000 PHP which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future. This loan will be the 17th loan taken out by Mryna from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income.
About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loan.use: To purchase piglets to raise.

loan.name: Elyn

texts.en:
Elyn T. is from the village of Barandias, Pangantucan, Bukidnon. She is 32 years old. Elyn is married and has three school-aged children. Elyn owns and operates a business butchering and selling meat in the market. The main source of income for the business comes from butchering & selling pork in the market. Elyn has been engaged in her business for over one year and earns approximately 5,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it.
In 2008, Elyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business. She has successfully repaid her last loan from HSPFI, which was for 8,000 PHP and was used to purchase additional pigs & as working capital.
Elyn is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP which will be used to to purchase additional pigs & as working capital. This loan will be her third from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand it.
About HSPFI:
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loan.use: purchasing additional pigs; working capital

loan.name: Jubilee

texts.en:
Jubilee A. is from the village of Misom, Baliangao. She is 21 years old, married, and has one infant child. Jubilee owns and operates a business engaged primarily in fish vending. The main source of income for the business comes from selling of ocean-caught fish in the local community. Jubilee has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month from it.
In 2007, Jubilee joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to do business. Jubilee has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used as additional capital for her business. Jubilee is requesting a new loan of 4,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fishing materials. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Jubilee from PMPC.
About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loan.name: Dante

texts.en: Dante C. is from the village of Batangan, Valencia City. He is 39 years old. Dante is married and has four school-aged children. Dante owns and operates a business. The main source of income for the business comes from providing motorcycle taxi, or habal-habal, services to local community members. Dante has been engaged in his business for over six years and earns approximately 4,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. He has successfully repaid his last loan from HSPFI, which was for 8,000 PHP and was used to purchase materials needed to provide service. Dante is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP which will be used to to repair a transport vehicle used in the business. This loan will be his third from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand it. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. loan.name: Su

texts.en: Su T. N. was born in 1965. She has a store that sells wood furniture. She has two children. Her husband takes part in social organization in her village. Everybody loves him. Her family has a monthly income of about 5,000,000 Vietnamese dong (VND). She has participated in SEDA since 2006 and repaid punctually. In this loan cycle, she would like to borrow 5,450,000 VND in order to expand her store.

loan.use: expanding furniture store

loan.name: Rowena's Group

texts.en:
Rowena O. is from the town of Namillangan Ifugao. She is 35 years old. Rowena is the group leader of a 11-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Rowena O..
Rowena is married and has three school-aged children. Rowena owns and operates a clothing business. The main source of income for the business comes from selling second hand clothes within their village. Rowena has been engaged in her business for over eight years and earns approximately 2500 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it.
In 2010, Rowena joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to do business. Rowena is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional clothes to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Rowena from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand it.
About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loan.name: Servilla

texts.en:
Servilla N. is from the village of Brgy. Nagcuartelan, Aritao, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 49 years old. Servilla is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Servilla makes and sells food. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from preparing and selling cooked food for daily meals. In 2008, Servilla joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Servilla has successfully repaid a previous loan of 13000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Servilla is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the fifth loan taken out by Servilla from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.
About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fishers, and small-business entrepreneurs.

loan.name: Trinidad

texts.en:
Trinidad R. is from the village of Unidos. She is 60 years old and is married with eight adult children.
Trinidad owns and operates a business planting and harvesting rice for sale. She has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.
In 2006, Trinidad joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase fertilizer such as manure.
Trinidad is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be her 3rd from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.
About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loan.name: Merly's Group

texts.en: Merly J. is from Bagong Silang, Santiago City. She is 51 years old and is the group leader of a 7-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. loan.name: Barbara

texts.en:
At the age of 54, Barbara C. is still single she really works hard to support her needs. In order to earn a living she ventures in rice retailing in their community. Barbara usually earns approximately 4000 PHP a month in these activities. With this income she has been able to purchase her daily needs. Barbara has been engaged in her business for over 2 years. Barbara lives in the village of Allinguingan 3rd.
In 2008, Barbara joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Barbara has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. To make a living, Maricel owns & operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. Maricel has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

Maricel has successfully repaid a previous loan of 9000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. loan.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loan.name: Keal

texts.en: Mrs. Keal H. earns a living by raising pigs in a pigpen behind her house. She raises them both for their offspring and for slaughter. In addition, she also sells fritters to her neighbors for extra profit. Her husband has the skill of making wooden furniture by hand and uses his knowledge to earn a living. The couple has two children who are enrolled in school. Keal H. has raised a lot of piglets and she had hoped to sell them to buyers four months after she began raising them. Unfortunately, the pigs are not big enough, due to the lack of food. To help solve this problem, Keal H. has requested a loan to buy many sacks of pig feed to fatten her pigs. She will use the rest of the loan towards purchasing piglets for her stall.

loan.use: To buy many sacks of pig feed to fatten her pigs.

loan.name: Benkadi 1 Group

texts.fr: Maries majoritairement dans des familles polygames, les dix membres du groupe Benkadi 1 de Bnbougou ont en moyenne 41 ans et 3 enfants. Elles vivent toutes dans le village de Bnbougou dans la commune rurale de Pelengana dans la rgion de Sgou (4me rgion administrative du Mali). Elles se sont connues travers des liens de mariage, de voisinage et de parent. Dans le but daugmenter leurs superficies de culture, elles ont fait recours Soro Yiriwaso et sont leur 2me cycle de prt de campagne. Des spculations comme le mil, le fonio et le nib seront cultives par les membres du groupe. Madame Sitan Dembl compte utiliser son prt pour acheter 3 sacs de complexe crale, 4 dabas et recruter la main duvre pour les activits de labour et de sarclage dans ses champs. Elle se ravitaille en intrants agricoles au grand march de Sgou, en main duvre avec lassociation des jeunes et des femmes du village. Elle compte produire 10 sacs de mil, 6 sacs de fonio, 2 sacs de nib et faire des bottes avec des fanes de nib sur sa surface de culture de 3 hectares. Une partie de la production est auto consomme tandis que le reste est vendu avec les bottes pour prendre en charge les soins de sant et les frais de scolarisation des enfants. Madame Sitan Dembl limage des autres femmes du groupe a pour objectif dassurer lauto suffisance alimentaire dans le village.
texts.en:
Predominantly married into polygamous families, the ten members of the group Benkadi 1 of Bnbougou are 41 years old and have 3 children, on average. They all live in the village of Bnbougou in the rural commune of Pelengana in the Sgou region (4th administrative region of Mali). They know one another through their marital, parentage and neighborhood ties. With the goal of increasing their cultivable land, they appealed to Soro Yiriwaso and are on their 2nd farm loan. Crops like millet, fonio (a species of millet from Mali), and black-eyed peas will be cultivated by the members of the group. Mrs. Sitan Dembl expects to use her loan to buy 3 bags of complex fertilizer and 4 axes, and to recruit the manual labor needed for the labor and hoeing activities in the fields. She gets fresh agricultural supplies at the big market in Sgou, and the manual labor from the association of young people and women in the village. She expects to produce 10 bags of millet, 6 bags of fonio, 2 bags of black-eyed peas and to make boots with the tops of the black-eyed pea plants from her 3 hectare cultivable area. She will use a part of what is produced herself, while the rest will be sold with the boots to care for the health needs and schooling costs of her children. Mrs. Sitan Dembl, like the other women of the group, also wants to assure the village's self-sufficiency in providing food.

Translated from French by Martha Schmitz, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: To buy fertilizers (complex fertilizers), small tools (axes), and to hire manual labor

loan.name: Din

texts.en: Mr. Din M., 36, is a village man living in Kompong Tom Province. He is a local crop farmer growing rice, vegetables, and some fruit on his own farmland. He was married and has three children who live together in the family home. To facilitate the work on the farm, his wife works in the farm fields frequently alongside him. Growing crops is an annual action with which the couple has had great success. They are able to plant the crops at least twice a year by following both rainy and dry seasons. Din M. is looking for a loan to use towards purchasing fertilizers, insecticides, and seeds for planting.

loan.use: To use towards purchasing fertilizers, insecticides, and seeds for planting.

loan.name: Djamadjigui 1 Group

texts.fr: Maries majoritairement dans des grandes familles polygamiques, les six membres du groupe Djamadjigui 1 ont en moyenne 42 ans et 4 enfants. Elles habitent b toutes dans le village de Moudjirila dans la commune urbaine de Sgou (4me rgion administrative du Mali) et se sont connues travers des liens de mariage, de voisinage et de parent. Dans le but daugmenter leurs superficies cultiver, elles ont fait recours Soro Yiriwaso et sont leur 2me cycle de prt de campagne. Le mil, le fonio, larachide et le riz seront cultivs par les membres du groupe. Madame Alimata Traor compte utiliser son prt pour acheter 3 sacs de complexe crale, 25kg de semence darachide, 3 bidons dherbicide et recruter la main duvre pour les activits de labour et de sarclage dans ses champs. Elle se ravitaille en intrants agricoles au grand march de Sgou, en main duvre avec lassociation des jeunes et des femmes du village. Elle compte produire 15 sacs darachide et 10 sacs de mil avec sa superficie de culture de 2 hectares. Une partie de la production est auto consomme tandis que le reste est vendu afin de prendre en charge les soins de sant des enfants et des condiments du foyer. Madame Alimata Traor espre raliser 75.000FCFA en fin de campagne.
texts.en:
The six members of the Djamadjigui 1 group, married and living for the most part in large polygamous families, are on the average 42 years of age and have 4 children. They all live in the village of Moudjirila in the township of Sgou (the fourth administrative region of Mali) and know each other as relatives by blood or marriage or as neighbors. In order increase their workable land, they have turned to Soro Yiriwaso and are now on their second agricultural loan. The group members will cultivate millet, fonio [ a millet species common to West Africa], peanuts and rice. Mrs. Alimata Traor plans to use her loan to purchase 3 bags of complex fertilizers, 25 kg [55 lbs] of peanut seed, 3 cans of herbicide and to recruit manual laborers for working and weeding the fields. She purchases agricultural inputs at the big market of Sgou and recruits laborers through the local young peoples association and the womens association. She plans to produce 15 bags of peanuts and 10 bags of millet on her land plot of 2 hectares [about 5 acres]. Part of the produce will be consumed by the family, and the remainder will be sold to provide for the childrens healthcare expenses and household condiments. At the end of the season, Mrs. Alimata Traor hopes to earn 75,000 West African Francs.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: Purchasing complex fertilizers, peanut seed & herbicides and paying for manual labor

loan.name: Asgar

texts.en: Asgar Q. is a 32 year old farmer who breeds sheep and cows in the small village of Saatli. He has five years of experience in this field. Asgar is married and has two children. He sells sheep to the local caf owners and to butchers. He uses cows to produce milk products for his family. Now he would like to expand his business and to purchase more sheep and one milking cow to sell milk and milk products to the local people and stores. For this purpose he applied for 900 AZN.

loan.use: To purchase four sheep and one milking cow.

loan.name: Nazli

texts.en: Nazli S. is a 45 year old woman who has been engaged in farming and cattle breeding for the past 10 years. She is married and has three children. She and her husband produce seasonal fruits and vegetables and at the same time buy small cattle, fatten them, raise and sell them in the livestock bazaar. Nazli applied for 1000 AZN in order to purchase more cattle as this is the main financial source for her family.

loan.use: To purchase two cattle.

loan.name: Feride

texts.en: Feride N. is a 55 year old woman who breeds cattle in the small village of Saatli. She is married and has three children. Feride applied for 1000 AZN in order to purchase more cattle and sheep. Her primary customers are local butchers. Once a month her husband takes animals for sale to the livestock bazaar. Feride wishes to improve her life conditions and to increase her income with this loan.

loan.use: To purchase four sheep and one cow.

loan.name: Pat

texts.en: Mrs. Pat H. is a 43-year-old farmer and mother. She was blessed with six children, two of whom are married and the other four are single. To help with the responsibility for family expenses, three of her daughters are employed in the garment factory. Pat H. has another financial earner in her husband who is a skilled producer of handmade wooden beds, from which he earns a living. Recently, Pat H.s husband got many orders for beds from his customers but he lacks items to meet this orders. Therefore, Pat H. decided to ask for a Kiva loan for her husband to use to buy raw materials to make additional beds for his customers.

loan.use: To buy raw materials to make additional beds for his customers.

loan.name: Susanna

texts.en: Susanna P. lives in Hatsavan village of Syunik marz in Armenia. Together, with her husband and two children, Susanna and her family are occupied in breeding cattle and in land cultivation. Susanna is a very enthusiastic woman willing to improve her familys condition. This loan will help her buy some livestock.

loan.use: For buying livestock.

loan.name: David

texts.en:
David C. is a 30 year old married father of two children. He has a wife who is 28 years old and is a housewife. David runs a barter trade business popularly known as 'mali kwa mali' in swahili. His business has been in operation for the last seven years.
This marks David's first borrowing from KADET and with the money he plans to purchase business goods for his businesses i.e washing basins and utensils. His major customers include the local passersby and retailers.
In the future David hopes to become a successful businessman.

loan.use: To purchase business goods for his businesses i.e washing basins and utensils.

loan.name: Djamadjigui 2 Group

texts.fr: Maries majoritairement dans des grandes familles polygamiques, les six membres du groupe Djamadjigui 2 ont en moyenne 40 ans et 3 enfants. Elles habitent toutes dans le village de Moudjirila dans la commune urbaine de Sgou (4me rgion administrative du Mali) et se sont connues travers des liens de mariage et de parent. Dans le but daugmenter leurs superficies de cultures, elles ont fait recours Soro Yiriwaso et sont leur 2me cycle de prt de campagne. Le mil, le fonio, larachide et le riz sont les spculations cultives par les membres du groupe. Madame Mariam Traor compte utiliser son prt pour acheter, 2 sacs de complexe crale, 20kg de semence darachide et recruter la main duvre pour les activits de labour et de sarclage dans ses champs. Elle se ravitaille en intrants agricoles au grand march de Sgou, en main duvre avec lassociation des jeunes et des femmes du village. Elle espre produire 13 sacs darachide, 6sacs de mil et 3sacs de fonio avec sa superficie de culture de 1,50 hectare. La production du mil et du fonio est auto consomme tandis que celle darachide est vendue pour la prise en charge des soins de sant des enfants, des denres alimentaires et des cas sociaux. Madame Mariam Traor tout comme les autres femmes du groupe a pour objectif de faire llevage des petits ruminants qui par la suite peut lui permettre davoir ses propres bufs de labour.
texts.en:
Predominantly married into large polygamous families, the six members of the group Djamadjigui 2 are on average 40 years old and have 3 children. They all live in the village of Moudjirila in the urban community of Sgou (4th administrative region of Mali) and know one another through marital and parental ties. With the goal of increasing their cultivable land, they appealed to Soro Yiriwaso and are on their second farm loan. Millet, fonio (a millet grown in Mali), peanuts and rice are the crops cultivated by the members of the group. Mrs. Mariam Traor expects to use her loan to buy 2 bags of complex fertilizer, 20 kg of peanut seeds and to recruit the manual labor for the labor and hoeing activities in the fields. She gets her supply of agricultural inputs at the large market in Sgou, and her manual labor from the association of young people and women of the village. She hopes to produce 13 bags of peanuts, 6 bags of millet and 3 bags of fonio on her 1.5 hectares of cultivable land. The millet and fonio she produces she consumes herself, while the peanuts produced are sold to pay for the health needs of her children, perishable foods and social cases. Mrs. Mariam Traor, like all the other women of the group, has the objective of raising small ruminant animals, which will eventually allow them to have their own steer for labor.

Translated from French by Martha Schmitz, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: To buy fertilizers (complex fertilizers), peanut seeds, and to use manual labor for labor and hoeing.

loan.name: Tuyet

texts.en: Tuyet T. Dinh was born in 1974. She has four children (two sons and two daughters). She breeds poultry (about 60 chickens). Her husband is a carpenter. He earns a monthly income. Her family has a monthly income of about 4,000,000 VND. She has participated in SEDA since 2006 and repaid punctually. For this loan, she would like to borrow 5,450,000 VND in order to breed poultry.

loan.use: To breed poultry

loan.name: Kheav

texts.en: Mr. Kheav R. is 43 years old, married and devoted to his five children who are students in the local public school. In his time away from school, one of his sons is a fisherman. Kheav R. is a local merchant who sells salt and vegetables in bulk door-to-door around his community. Another source of his income is from working with his wife to grow mushrooms on their own farmland located next to their house. Kheav R. owns other village land, on which he has been planning to build a new house for his child to live in but his goal does not come true because he is lacking funds. To achieve his goal, Kheav R. has decided to seek a loan for $1,100 to add to his savings in order to construct a new house. Mr. Kheav R. was busy at his business, so his wife was photographed instead.

loan.use: To construct a new house.

loan.name: Pamela

texts.en:
Pamela O. is a hardworking lady based in Kisumu, a lakeside city in Western Kenya along Lake Victoria. She is married to Agripa Onguka, a college teacher. They have three children between 8 and 16 years old.
Pamela operates a salon and boutique at the town center in Kisumu city where she sells new clothes and salon materials like weaves, pieces for hair plaiting and many more beauty products. From this business, Pamela makes a monthly income of around Kshs. 33,400 ($417).Confidently, Pamela has operated this business for the last 13 years and therefore she has wide experience. She is taking her fourth loan from Kadet Limited and she is confident that she will be able to pay in full without default. She intends to use the loan to buy weaves, new clothes and pieces for plaiting.
From the anticipated profits, Pamela will ensure she uses it to educate her children and ensure that their living standards improve for the better. Apart from this, she has plans to open other businesses and her plan at the moment is to open the popular money transfer business service (locally known as M-pesa). For sure, the sky is the limit for Pamela. She hopes to get a Kiva lender to help her realize these plans.

loan.use: To buy new clothes and pieces for hair plaiting.

loan.name: Tissiri 1 Group

texts.fr: Les huit femmes du groupe Tissiri 1 sont maries majoritairement dans des grandes familles polygames, avec en moyenne 34 ans et 5 enfants. Elles vivent toutes dans le village de Siradjankoro dans la commune rurale de Pelengana dans la rgion de Sgou (4me rgion administrative du Mali) et se sont connues travers des liens de mariage, de voisinage et de parent. Dans le but d'augmenter leurs superficies de culture, elles ont fait recours Soro Yiriwaso et sont leur 1ier cycle de prt de campagne. Les membres du groupe vont cultiver le mil, larachide et le fonio. Madame Fatoumata Traor compte utiliser son prt pour acheter 25kg de semences darachide, un sac de complexe crale et recruter la main duvre pour les activits de labour et de rcolte pour son champ darachide. Elle se ravitaille en intrants agricole la foire Cinzana Gare et en main duvre avec lassociation des jeunes et des femmes du village. Avec une superficie de 2,50 hectares, Madame Fatoumata Traor espre produire 18 sacs darachide et 8 sacs de mil. Toute la production du mil serait auto consomme tandis que celle darachide sera vendue pour satisfaire les besoins du foyer en condiments et soins de sant des enfants. Madame Fatoumata Traor limage des autres femmes du groupe Tissiri a pour objectif dassurer lauto suffisance alimentaire dans le village et faire de llevage des petits ruminants.
texts.en:
The eight women of the group Tissiri 1 are predominantly married into large polygamous families, are on average 34 years old and have 5 children. They all live in the village of Siradjankoro in the rural community of Pelengana in the region of Sgou (4th administrative region of Mali) and know one another through marital, parental and neighborhood ties. With the goal of increasing their cultivable lands, they appealed to Soro Yiriwaso and are on their 1st farm loan. The members of the group are going to cultivate millet, peanuts and fonio (a type of millet produced in Mali). Mrs. Fatoumata Traor expects to use her loan to buy 25 kg of peanut seeds, a bag of complex fertilizers, and to recruit the manual labor for the labor and harvesting for the peanut fields. She refreshes her supply of agricultural inputs at the fair in Cinzana Gare and gets her manual labor from an association of young people and women from the village. With 2.5 hectares of land, Mrs. Fatoumata Traor hopes to produce 18 bags of peanuts and 8 bags of millet. She will consume all the millet she produces, while the peanuts she produces will be sold to satisfy the household needs in condiments and to care for the health of her children. Mrs. Fatoumata Traor, like the other women of the Tissiri group, has as her objective the dietary self-sufficiency of the village and to raise small ruminant animals.

Translated from French by Martha Schmitz, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: To buy peanut seeds, complex fertilizer, and to use manual labor for the labor and harvesting

loan.name: Cay

texts.en: Cay T. T. was born in 1956. She not only grows rice but she breeds 200 chickens too. She has two children who are married. Her husband is a carpenter. She has a monthly income of about 3,000,000 VND. She has participated in SEDA since 2006 and repaid punctually. For this loan, she would like to borrow 5,450,000 VND to buy food for her chickens.

loan.use: To buy food for her chickens
