texts.es: Damiana viaja a la comunidad de Alpachaca que se encuentra a 3 horas de la ciudad de Ayacucho de donde compra quesos de los productores para luego venderlos en la ciudad de casa en casa, tambin lleva al distrito de Pacaycasa y adems vende alimento para animales que compra en los molinos, Damiana es viuda y tiene 6 hijos de los cuales 1 vive con ella, Damiana es socia del Banco Comunal Bonanza hace 1 ao y lo que mas le agrada son las capacitaciones de salud, Damiana necesita un prstamo de 900 soles dinero que ser invertido en la compra de quesos. Sus sueos son ahorrar para la vejez y adquirir propiedades que le den seguridad para el futuro.
texts.en:
Damiana travels to the community Alpachaca, located three hours from Ayacucho, to buy cheese from local producers, which she then sells from door-to-door in her hometown as well as the district of Pacaycasa. Damiana also sells food for animals, which she buys from the mills. Damiana is a widow with six children, one of whom lives with her. She has been a member of the community bank Bonanza for the past year, and what pleases her most is the health training. Damiana needs a loan of 900 soles, money she will invest in the purchase of cheese. Her dreams are saving money for old age and acquiring property that will offer her security in the future.

Translated from Spanish by Lydia Brantley, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: Buying cheese

loan.name: Juana

texts.es: Juana es socia del Banco Comunal Bonanza hace 3 aos y aprendi a tener una buena atencin a sus clientes. Juana es casada y tiene 4 hijos que ya viven fuera D. casa, Juana junto a su esposo tienen una tienda en su casa en donD. venden abarrotes en general, helados, actividad que realiza todos los das. Juana solicita un prstamo D. 1050 soles dinero que ser invertido en la compra arroz, azcar y aceite. Juana suea con tener lo necesario para vivir tranquila.
texts.en:
Juana has been a member of the community bank Bonanza for the past three years. She has learned good customer service skills. Juana is married and has four children who live outsiD. the home. Juana and her husband have a store in their home where they sell groceries and ice cream. They work every day. Juana is asking for a loan of 1050 soles, money she will invest in the purchase of rice, sugar, and oil. Juana dreams of having what she needs to live peacefully.

Translated from Spanish by Lydia Brantley, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: Purchase of rice, sugar, and oil

loan.name: Magaly

texts.es:
Magaly C. M., se desempea hace tres aos labores como confecciones de chompas para nios y adultos, uniformes escolares, chalinas, gorras y otras prendas de temporada, todo a base de tejidos de lana e hilo, dichas prendas se elaboran con maquinas de tejer.
Para complementar su habilidad y mejorar su producto se prepar en la CETPRO San Juan Bautista con el objetivo de especializarse ms en el rubro, para as obtener mayores ingresos y solventar los gastos de su hogar con el apoyo de su esposo, quien provee otro ingreso en su hogar, adems comprar materiales de trabajo, comparte , Magaly tambin se dedica a vender pasteles, bocaditos, chocolates para eventos especiales como cumpleaos, quince aos, bautizos, etc; as fue como logr comprar una mquina de tejer mas renovada.. Actualmente ahorra dinero para comprar materiales de trabajo (hilo, agujas, lana de colores, etc), y asi seguir esforzndose para adquirir 02 maquinas mas que le es indispensable para elaborar sus tejidos. El prstamo que necesita es para invertir en la compra de materiales de trabajo y pagar algunas deudas pendientes.
texts.en:
Magaly C. M. has worked three years making sweaters for adults and children, school uniforms, scarves, hats, and other seasonal items. Everything is done in wool or linen fabric and made on a sewing machine. To improve her skills and better her product, Magaly studied at the CETPRO San Juan Bautista with the objective of specializing in the field so she could make more money. This would allow her to settle household expenses along with her husband, who provides the household's other source of income, as well as buy necessary materials for her work. Magaly also sells cakes, sandwiches, and chocolates for special events like birthday parties, quinceaeras, baptisms, etc. Through her catering business she was able to buy a better sewing machine. Currently, Magaly is saving money to buy materials for sewing (thread, needles, colored wool, etc.) so she can continue striving to obtain two additional sewing machines needed to make her fabrics. The loan she needs is for the purchase of work materials and paying off some outstanding debt.

Translated from Spanish by Lydia Brantley, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: Buying materials to make fabric

loan.name: Anonymous
loan.use: to buy construction materials to invest in a new roof for his house, to plaster some walls in his house, and for other personal expenses

loan.name: Miskyunu-Phiry Group

texts.es:
El banco comunal Mujeres en Accin actualmente se encuentra en el VII ciclo y est conformado por personas trabajadoras y emprendedoras que buscan a cada momento las oportunidades para salir adelante y con su esfuerzo diario entregar un mejor futuro a sus hijos. Las reuniones del banco comunal son cada treinta das en la casa D. la socia Florentina que est ubicado en la comunidad D. Phiry, Ollantaytambo. La comunidad D. Phiry se encuentra a dos horas D. la ciudad del Cusco. La mayora D. los pobladores se dedica a la agricultura y la ganadera.
Soledad, tiene 25 aos y tiene un hijo, ella naci en la ciudad D. Ollantaytambo y actualmente vive en la comunidad D. Phiry. Hace ocho aos atrs, Soledad abri un restaurante, en su domicilio, donD. venD. comida a sus vecinos. Soledad tambin se dedica a la crianza D. animales menores como por ejemplo cuyes pero para consumo.
Con su prximo prstamo, Soledad espera recibir S/. 300 soles. Por el momento, su restaurante esta modestamente implementado con las necesidades bsicas. Le gustara emplear el dinero para comprar ms insumos como por ejemplo arroz, azcar, fideos y muchas cosas ms. El sueo D. la socia es convertirse en una prospera empresaria y desea abrir varios restaurantes en la ciudad D. Ollantaytambo.
Soledad es una D. las socias fundadoras del banco comunal y la escogieron como la secretaria porque es una persona puntual y responsable. Ya son varias veces que est en el cargo y le va muy bien gracias al carisma y buena voluntad que tiene.
texts.en:
The Community Bank "Women in Action" are currently on their 7th loan cycle. The group is maD. up of very hard working individuals that are always on the lookout for opportunities for success. With their daily efforts they hope to proviD. a better future for their children. The Community Bank meetings are held every 30 days in the home of Florentina, a member of the bank, located in the community of Phiry, Ollantaytambo. The community of Phiry is located 2 hours from the city of Cusco. The majority of the population are farmers. Soledad is 25 yaers old and she has a won. She was born in the city of Ollantaytambo but she currently lives in the community of Phiry. Eight years ago Soledad opened a restaurant in her house where she sells foods to her neighbours. Soledad also raises livestock such as guinea pigs, for consumption. The loan she has requested is in the amount of S/300 soles. At the moment her restaurant is modestly stocked with the basic necessities. She would like to invest the funds to purchase ingredients such as rice, sugar, spaghetti and various other items. The dream of this member is to become a successful business woman and would like to operate several franchise locales in the city of Ollantaytambo. Soledad is one of the founding members of this Community Bank and she has been elected as secretary of the group because she is very punctual and responsible. She has been in this position various times before and it has worked out very well thanks to her charisma and positive outlook.

Translated from Spanish by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: To purchase ingredients such as rice, sugar, pasta and other items.

loan.name: Anonymous
loan.use: To carry out home improvements.

loan.name: Anonymous
loan.use: To carry out home improvements.

loan.name: Romeo

texts.en:
Romeo L. Jr. is from the village of Liloan, Bonifacio. He is 29 years old and is married with one infant child.
Romeo owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling daily-use products such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month.
In 2010, Romeo joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her first from GDMPC. loan.name: Bella

texts.en:
Bella E., age 40, is working hard to cover daily expenses and pay for her children's education. She and her husband, Leonardo, age 52, grow pineapples and raise hogs on their small farm, while also generating income from an apartment they rent out. A recent typhoon did extensive damage to the farm and Bella is looking to rebuild with the help of a 10,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) loan to buy additional fertilizer for her pineapple plants. She has been a member of the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) since 2005 and has consistently participated in weekly fellowship meetings*.
Bella hopes that someday she will save enough to be able to purchase more farmland and generate enough income to help her children complete their studies.
* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loan.name: Rowilma

texts.en:
Rowilma H., age 32, and her husband, Norberto, work hard to cover their daily living expenses and to pay for their children's education. For the past 10 years, Rowilma has been running a general store in Silang, Cavite selling meat, groceries, and prepaid credits for cell phone users through electronic loading.
Recently, customers have been seeking more variety in her store. Rowilma would like to be able to expand the number of goods she sells and add to her existing meat and cell phone prepaid credits inventory with the help of a PHP 8,000 loan. Rowilma has been a member of the Center for Community Transformation since 2008 and has consistently participated in weekly meetings.*
Rowilma hopes that eventually income generated through her business will be able to fully fund her children's education. She also dreams of expanding her business and someday purchasing a freezer to store the meat she sells.
* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

Rufina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Rufina is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 10th loan taken out by Rufina from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.
About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.
*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loan.name: Julieta

texts.en:
Julieta Z., from the village of Allinguigan 3rd, is 48 years old and single. To make a living, Julieta owns and operates a specialized retail store selling AVON cosmetics and apparel products in the local community. Engaged in her business for over 10 years, she earns approximately 4000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Julieta joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having repaid her previous loan of 9000 PHP from ASKI that was used to purchase additional products to sell, she is now requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP for the same purpose. This will be Julieta's fourth loan from ASKI, and she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her enterprise.

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

loan.name: Modesto

texts.en:
Modesto D. S., aged 43, and his wife Hernani, are blessed in their marriage with a happy family. They live in Sabutan, Silang, Cavite. Modesto and his wife run a small fruit stand that sells pineapple, bananas and corn among other items, and which generates 18,000 PHP per month in earnings.
Modesto would like to expand his business with a loan of 10,000 PHP, which he will use to purchase additional varieties of fruit to meet the demands of his customers. He hopes that the additional variety will allow him to generate more revenue and increase the family's savings. Modesto hopes that eventually the business will generate enough revenue to allow him and his wife to have and support children.
Modesto has been a member of Kiva partner, the Center for Community Transformation (CCT), since 2005 and has consistently paid his weekly dues during fellowship meetings* . He is currently on his 12th loan with CCT. * All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. They gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loan.use: To purchase additional fruits to sell

loan.name: Anonymous
loan.use: to buy construction materials to improve her house such as: cements, sand, gravel, etc.

loan.name: Edzel

texts.en:
Edzel L., aged 47, and his wife Evelyn L., sell groceries at their general store. They also own an apartment that they rent out for a small profit. Together, the businesses generate roughly 19,000 PHP per month, which the couple uses to cover daily household expenses and to send their children to school.
Edzel is seeking a loan of 26,000 PHP to cover the repair costs for damage that was done to the apartment during a recent typhoon. He will also use the loan to help with the purchase of additional inventory for the family's general store. Edzel hopes the maintenance in the apartment will increase earnings, and that additional inventory for the store will help the family to expand their business.
Edzel has been a member of Kiva partner, the Center for Community Transformation (CCT)*, since 2005 and has consistently paid his weekly dues. Edzel is on his 12th loan through CCT, and hopes that the continued growth of his business will allow him to fully fund his children's education. * All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loan.use: To repair his rental apartment and buy stock for store

loan.use: to buy construction materials to build a wall, such as: stone, sand, cement, etc.

loan.name: Shirley

texts.en:
Shirley A., age 41, and her husband, Thomas A., a farmer and driver, age 41, are working to put their four children through high school and college. They live in Silang, Cavite.
Shirley has been running a decorative flower and plant store as well as a Jeepney and tricycle operation business for the past five years, and hopes that the PHP 12,200 generated from these endeavors each month will continue to support her family.
Shirley has been a regular member of the Center for Community Transformation (CCT)* since 2006 and is on her eighth loan. Shirley is consistent in paying her dues because she uses the money she borrows to buy more stock for her flower business and to help out with costs that arise through her Jeepney and tricycle business.
Shirley is currently looking for a PHP 10,000 loan to help pay for additional fertilizer for her plant farm, which was damaged in a recent typhoon, and to help cover registration fees for the Jeepney and tricycle. Shirley hopes that the additional capital will help her fully recover from the typhoon and allow her to begin expanding her flower selling business. She hopes for a stable, happy, and peaceful life for her and her family.
* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loan.use: Registration fees for their own jeepney and fertilizers for their flower farm

loan.name: Florenda's Group

texts.en:
Florenda S. is from the town of Dumabato Sur Maddela, Quirino. She is 43 years old. Florenda is the group leader of an 11-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Florenda S..
Florenda is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Florenda owns & operates a business making & selling general household furniture to local businesses and community members. Florenda has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.
In 2010, Florenda joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Florenda is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase raw materials to make additional furniture. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Florenda from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.
About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.
